(L. Shi), (D. Liu), (S. Zhao) Water splitting powered by clean electricity is a sustainable and promising approach to produce green hydrogen. Currently, noble metal (e.g. Iridium, Ruthenium, Platinum)-based catalysts are most widely used for water splitting electrolysis. However, noble metal-based catalysts often suffer from multiple disadvantages, including high cost, low selectivity and poor durability. The emergence of metal-organic framework nanosheets (MOFNSs) attracts significant attention due to their unique advantages. Here, a concise, yet comprehensive and critical, review of recent advances in the field of MOFNSs is provided. This review explains the fundamental oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalytic mechanisms as well as key characterization techniques for the structure-activity relationship study are discussed. Moreover, it discusses efficient design strategies and the brief research advances of MOFNSs in HER, OER, and bifunctional electrocatalysis, along with some challenges and opportunities. Graphical Abstract This review comprehensively summarizes recent research progresses in non-derivatized metal-organic framework nanosheets for water electrolysis from the design strategies of metal centers control, ligand regulation, defect engineering and composite components. Keywords Metal-organic framework nanosheets Electrocatalysis Water splitting Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction 1 Introduction As the increase of fossil fuels consumption, it is necessary to find innovative renewable and environment-friendly energy to handle currently faced severe environmental and energy challenges [1–4]. Hydrogen with zero-carbon emission and high calorific value of combustion (142, 351 kJ kg−1) has long been regarded as an ideal candidate to replace the traditional fuels. In the past years, various sustainable photo/thermal/electrochemical technologies have been developed to produce hydrogen [5–10]. Among these, electrochemical water splitting driven by renewable electricity from solar or wind energy is considered the most promising pathway to produce green hydrogen. In the process, it involves an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) which occurs at the anode and the cathode, respectively. At present, noble metal-based materials are the most active catalyst to overcome the kinetic sluggish of both OER and HER. Nevertheless, the scarcity and stricken stability of these materials seriously hinder their large-scale implementation [11]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop efficient but cost-effective non-noble metal water splitting electrocatalysts. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have shown great application potential in the field of catalysis due to their tunable morphologies, pore structure, diversity of metal ion or ligand selection, and large surface area [12]. In 1989, the professional concept of MOF was proposed by Hoskins et al. [13]. And then the term MOF was widely known after the frontier work of Yaghi and colleagues [14,15] in 1995. MOF materials have excellent editable genes, just like enzyme catalytic materials, which can catalyze a certain reaction in a targeted manner. In recent years, new progress has been made in the study of electrocatalytic water splitting of MOFs [16,17]. Many studies have demonstrated that MOF materials can be used as effective electrocatalysts for water electrolysis [18,19]. In particular, some MOF-derived materials have demonstrated excellent performance toward water electrolysis. However, the real active sites in these materials are difficult to pinpoint due to their ambiguous and uncontrollable structures, making them difficult for mechanism study and further enhancement of catalytic performance. In contrast, non-derived MOFs consist of metal nodes and organic ligands, forming the genetically programmable frameworks with well-defined structures and active centers. This inherent structural predictability allows for precise tuning of their catalytic activity, making non-derived MOFs highly attractive for electrocatalytic water splitting applications. In addition, various catalytic systems are essentially the same, especially in terms of intermediate states and reaction pathways. Whether it is photo/thermal/enzymatic catalysis or electrocatalysis, highly exposed active centers and controllable design strategies are the key to highly active catalytic materials. In order to accelerate the kinetics of HER and OER during the water splitting process, metal-organic framework nanosheets (MOFNSs) extended lateral dimensions and nano thicknesses have been developed. In 2010, two-dimensional (2D) MOF nanostructured materials have been fabricated on solid substrates using layer-by-layer or epitaxial growth methods [20]. Since the first 2D porous extended frameworks reported by the Yaghi's group [21] in 2012, the synthesis of MOF nanosheets has also gradually emerged [22–24]. Theoretically, MOFNSs offer several advantages over conventional bulk MOFs. Firstly, their increased surface area and abundance of unsaturated metal sites make them conducive for interacting with reactive substrates. Secondly, their nano-thickness reduces diffusion distances, facilitating material transfer during electrocatalysis and thereby boosting reaction rates. Thirdly, MOFNSs allow for the formation of vacancies, acting as shallow donors that can increase carrier concentration and enhance charge transfer within the material. In 2015, Marinescu and his colleague [25] integrated of cobalt dithiolene catalysts into a metal-organic surface for HER. In 2016, Zhao et al. [26] published the first-ever findings on a series of ultrathin MOFNSs with excellent activity for the electrocatalytic OER. Since then, MOFNSs have been widely investigated as electrocatalysts exhibiting excellent performance in both HER and OER (Fig. 1 ). Additionally, they exhibit effective bifunctional catalysis in overall electrolyzes for HER/OER, as well as in other important electrochemical processes in related devices. Although many reviews have been published on the applications of MOF-based materials in water splitting [27–29], few reviews summarize the non-derivatized MOFNSs from the perspective of regulatory engineering and give potential future development directions. In the past few years, great efforts have been made to promote the development of non-derivatized MOFNSs in water electrolysis, and substantial progress has been achieved in mechanistic understanding, catalyst design, and industrial and energy applications. Therefore, a timely review of this rapidly developing critical field is urgently needed. Therefore, a timely review on this rapidly evolving and critical field is highly desired. In this review, we offer a succinct yet all-encompassing overview of non-derivatized MOFNSs for water electrolysis. Firstly, it delves into the underlying mechanisms governing the catalytic processes of the fundamental OER and HER. At the same time, it also explores the characterization techniques employed to study the relationship between structure and activity. Finally, we systematically summarize the effective strategies employed in the design of MOFNSs and outlines the latest research developments in HER, OER, as well as bifunctional electrocatalysis. Additionally, the review highlights the challenges and opportunities that researchers will encounter in this field. Ultimately, we believe that this comprehensive review will inspire the wider scientific community to gain a deeper understanding of the fundamental mechanisms, current research status, and challenges associated with MOFNSs as electrocatalysts for water splitting. 2 Mechanism of water electrolysis Understanding the mechanism behind electrocatalytic water splitting is crucial for the rational design and controllable synthesis of effective catalysts. Non-derivatized MOFs possess the well-defined structures, which are well suited for the mechanism study of electrocatalytic water splitting. Their active centers are usually metal oxygen clusters and can be efficiently regulated by ligand functional groups. Various reaction mechanisms in non-derivatized MOF have been proposed and discussed to elucidate the electrocatalytic performance observed in different electrolytes. In this section, we briefly discuss the basic catalytic mechanisms of common non-derivatized MOFs for electrocatalytic OER and HER, aiming to provide insights for designing high-performance electrocatalysts for water splitting. 2.1 Oxygen evolution reaction The OER involves a complex four-electron transfer process with inherently slow reaction kinetics, which directly determine the overall efficiency of water splitting. Therefore, an in-depth understanding of the OER mechanism is essential to uncover the multifaceted redox catalytic processes occurring at the metal sites on the catalyst surface. There are three generally accepted OER mechanisms: Adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM), lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) and oxide pathway mechanism (OPM). The differences between these three mechanisms will be discussed as below, which is helpful to the development of highly efficient and stable OER electrocatalysts. 2.1.1 Adsorbate evolution mechanism As depicted in Fig. 2(a) , the AEM is driven by metal redox chemistry influenced by the properties of metal bands near the Fermi level [30,31]. This mechanism involves a series of electron-proton-transfer steps between the metal active sites and the adsorbed oxygen intermediates (*OH, *O and *OOH). Since the constant energy difference between the binding energies of *OH and *OOH (ΔG *OOH – ΔG *OH = 3.2 eV), optimal binding energies are necessary to balance adsorption and desorption processes. Ideally, a half binding energy of 1.6 eV should be distributed equally between the *OH to *O and *O to *OOH steps, leading to a theoretically minimum overpotential of 370 mV for the OER [32]. Therefore, breaking the scaling relationship is considered an effective strategy to reduce the overpotential in AEM-based MOF materials [33]. Despite their relatively high overpotential, AEM-based electrocatalysts generally exhibit excellent stability because of only minimal changes in the valence state of metal centers. 2.1.2 Lattice oxygen mechanism Unlike the AEM, the LOM involves oxygen redox chemistry due to the oxygen bands around the Fermi level, where a direct O-O coupling occurs between lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen intermediates (Fig. 2(B)) [30,31]. It is worth noting that the LOM can surpass the overpotential limits imposed by the scaling relationship prevalent in the traditional AEM, thereby offering a new approach to boost the OER activity. Nevertheless, the stability of LOM-based electrocatalysts remains a significant challenge because the continuous lattice oxygen participation inevitably results in the metal dissolution and even structure degradation [30]. Therefore, understanding the OER mechanisms is pivotal for the realization of the balance between activity and stability for MOF electrocatalysts. 2.1.3 Oxide pathway mechanism In addition to the AEM and LOM, the OPM has also proposed as an alternative pathway to explain the exceptional OER activity and stability. As shown in Fig. 2(C), the OPM primarily involves the *OH and *O intermediates and subsequent O-O coupling between two *O intermediates. This pathway can effectively avoid lattice oxygen participation and subsequent oxygen vacancy formation, thereby significantly enhancing the OER activity and stability. However, the OPM has more stringent triggering requirements on the geometric configuration of metal active sites, the appropriate distances between dual-metal centers are expected to enhance the O-O coupling process. For instance, embedding Ru atom arrays with MnO2 nanofibers can decrease the distance of dual-Ru sites compared to crystalline RuO2, which facilitates the OER mechanism transformation from AEM to OPM. Therefore, precise spatial of metal centers is a key precondition of OPM-type OER pathway [34]. 2.1.4 Other emerging mechanisms Along with substantial progress of the OER mechanisms, several emerging mechanisms are also proposed to fully explain the experimental OER performance. Recently, a newly light-triggered coupled oxygen evolution mechanism (COM) has been reported [35]. The metal and oxygen alternately serve as the redox center during deprotonation and oxygen-oxygen bonding process, which can bypass the potential limiting steps in the traditional AEM and LOM. Thus, the COM mechanism can effectively break through the drawbacks of conventional OER mechanisms and exhibit superior activity compared with previously reported OER electrocatalysts. Besides, a pH-dependent intramolecular hydroxyl nucleophilic attack (IHNA) mechanism has also been proposed for the enhanced formation of O–O bond, which provides an important insight into the critical role of electrolyte pH during electrocatalytic water oxidation [36]. In addition, some researchers have also studied the sulphur-oxygen exchange of sulphur-containing catalysts prior to the occurrence of OER to better explore the mechanism [37]. Through exploring these mechanisms, researchers can enhance the understanding of catalytic processes and activity origination, which in turn aids in the rational design of innovative MOF electrocatalysts. 2.2 Hydrogen evolution reaction The HER mechanisms are comparatively well-understood and primarily involve a two-step process (Fig. 2(D)). The initial step is the Volmer reaction, which entails the coupling of an adsorbed proton in acidic conditions, or a water molecule in neutral or alkaline environments, with an electron to form an adsorbed H* on the metal site. Following this, hydrogen molecules desorb through either the Heyrovsky or Tafel process. In the Heyrovsky step, the chemisorbed H* combines with another proton or water molecule from solution, which is then electrochemically reduced and desorbed as H2. Conversely, the Tafel pathway involves the combination of two adsorbed H*, leading to the direct chemical desorption of the hydrogen molecule. The former sequence of reactions is known as the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism, while the latter is termed the Volmer-Tafel mechanism. HER can thus proceed via either the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism or the Volmer-Tafel mechanism under both acidic and alkaline conditions. The experimental determination of the HER reaction mechanism often relies on analyzing the Tafel slope to identify which reaction (Volmer, Tafel, or Heyrovsky) acts as the rate-determining step (RDS) [38,39]. The hydrogen adsorption Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) is commonly regarded as a crucial parameter for assessing HER performance [40]. Ideally, the ΔG H* should be close to zero, indicating neither too strong nor too weak a bond with H-containing intermediates. The strength of hydrogen binding at the metal active sites significantly impacts HER kinetics: too weak a bond impedes H* adsorption (Volmer reaction), while too strong a bond prevents H* desorption (Heyrovsky or Tafel reaction). Therefore, controlling the hydrogen binding energy on the catalyst surface is essential for the design of effective HER electrocatalysts. As illustrated in the HER Volcano Diagram (Fig. 2(E)), platinum group metals (such as Pd, Pt, Rh, and Ir) exhibit an optimal ΔG H* near zero, thus making them highly active for HER. In contrast, metals like Cu, Ag, and Au, located to the right of the platinum group, typically display weaker hydrogen bonding, which hinders the H* desorption. Meanwhile, transitional metals such as Ni, Co, W, and Mo, distributed on the left, have stronger hydrogen bonding energies that are not conductive to the release of H* species. Thus, a deep understanding of these fundamental catalytic mechanisms is crucial for guiding the rational design of efficient HER electrocatalysts [41]. 3 Characterizations for structure-activity relationship With the growing demand to address energy and environmental challenges, electrocatalysis studies have increasingly shifted towards in-depth theoretical research and extensive practical applications. Advanced characterization tools are essential for exploring the fundamental properties and structure-activity relationships of materials at both atomic and electronic orbital levels. Through in-situ and ex-situ characterizations, researchers can investigate electrocatalytic processes and unravel reaction mechanisms. The rapid advancement of analytical methods has provided powerful techniques and equipment for precise characterization, which is crucial for establishing the correlation between structure and activity. Component characterization also plays a critical role in gathering qualitative and quantitative information about the metals and ligands present in the MOFNSs. 3.1 Structure characterizations The morphological and structural characterization is key to understanding of investigating the physicochemical properties of materials. Notley, unlike traditional metal materials and carbonized materials, MOFs have variable morphology and crystallinity, as well as a clear microstructure, so some special but necessary characterization techniques are needed to explore the structure of MOFs catalysts. A comprehensive analysis involving powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), selected area electron diffraction (SAED), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR), and Raman spectroscopy can be employed to study the crystallinity, crystalline phases, coordination interactions, electronic states, and defects present in MOFNSs. In addition, electron microscopy characterization, including scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), as well as more advanced techniques like in-situ and aberration-corrected TEM/STEM [42], allow for the examination and exploration of surface structure, size, and morphology for MOFNSs. Meanwhile, the thickness measurement of MOFNSs can be precisely achieved using an atomic force microscope (AFM). Although high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) or STEM have become routine structural characterization [43,44], they still remain challenge when examining MOFs due to their extreme electron beam sensitivity [45–47]. The emerging low-dose integrated differential phase contrast (iDPC) STEM technique is an effective method to guide the atomic-scale design of MOFs-based electrocatalysts (Fig. 3(a) ) [48]. The iDPC-STEM technique combines the phase contrast imaging capability of traditional differential phase contrast microscopy with the high spatial resolution of scanning transmission electron microscopy. This combination enables scientists to better understand the structure and composition of materials. It is a direct phase imaging process, where the higher the atomic number, the stronger the scattering and the brighter the signal (Fig. 3(B)) [49]. More information related to lighter elements can be obtained using iDPC-STEM compared to high-angle angular dark-field (HAADF), which is particularly valuable in studying MOFNSs. As illustrated in Fig. 3(C), the iDPC-STEM image of 2D Ni-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) reveals that the Ni-O 2D layer is separated by BDC molecules, aligning with the predicted structural model. Geometric phase analysis (GPA) demonstrates that the introduction of Fe3+ or 2-aminoterephthalate (ATA) significantly alters E xx (strain perpendicular to 2D layer), E yy (strain parallel with 2D layers), and E xy (shear strain), indicating the presence of a 2D layer separation [50]. Additionally, small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) and wide-angle X-Ray scattering (WAXS) are commonly employed to reveal structural, elemental, and atomic information of MOFs (Fig. 3(D)). SAXS has nanometer resolution, making it suitable for larger-scale bulk microstructures, while WAXS has atomic resolution, allowing for the study of atomic details. Both these techniques can be performed simultaneously and interchangeably, as they require the detector and sample to be adjusted closer or further apart. Researchers can use SAXS and WAXS to quantitatively and qualitatively study crystal details of MOFs, including pore surface features, pore shape, particle size distribution, specific surface area, spatial distribution and pore network structure [51,52]. For example, Fischer et al. [53] employed grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (GIWAXS) technique to analysis the MOF films, demonstrating that reduced nucleation in solution can increase the desired orientation fraction (2D powder fraction) of UiO-66 on UiO-67 prepared by steam-assisted conversion (Fig. 3(E)). Similarly, the structural feature of the ultrathin MOFNSs was analyzed using SAXS in our pervious work [26]. The SAXS analysis revealed four distinct reflections corresponding to the crystallographic planes (200), (001), (201), and (2–01) as illustrated in Fig. 3(F). According to the calculated Bravais-Friedel-Donnay-Harker (BFDH) crystal morphology derived from the SAXS pattern, it was determined that the NiCo-UMOFNs possess a two-dimensional sheet-like morphology, which is well consistent with the experimental and simulated reflections. Furthermore, since non-derivatized MOFNSs usually have metal oxygen clusters as active centers for electrocatalytic water splitting, it is also very important to identify the fine structure of metal clusters by advanced characterization techniques. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) is also a versatile and powerful technique to analysis the fine structure of the metal active center. It reveals information about the local chemical and physical environment of specific elements. XAFS is further divided into two regions: X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). XANES refers to the region near the absorption edge of an element (typically within about 50 eV). It provides information about the oxidation state and coordination environment of the absorbing atom, such as the types of atoms surrounding it and their electronic states. EXAFS covers the energy range extending beyond the XANES region (typically up to 1000 eV or more). It provides detailed information about the distances, coordination numbers, and disorder of the atoms surrounding the absorbing atom. As exampled by the NiCo-UMOFNs, the EXAFS spectra provided insights into the structural properties at atomic level (Fig. 3(G)) [26]. The dominant peak at 1.60 Å is attributed to the first shell coordination of the metal (M) with oxygen (O). Meanwhile, the relatively weak peaks at 2.35, 2.86, and 3.24 Å were associated with higher shell contributions in M–C, M–O, and M–M, respectively. 3.2 Performance evaluation The schematic illustration of electrocatalytic water splitting is depicted in Fig. 3(H) [33]. The electrocatalytic performance is typically characterized using electrochemical workstations. Various measurement techniques, including but not limited to cyclic voltammetry (CV), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), chronoamperometry (CA), chronopotentiometry (CP), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), are commonly employed to assess the performances of electrocatalysts. In general, LSV polarization curves are frequently used to evaluate the catalyst performance. The onset potential corresponds to the potential at a specific current density of 1 or −1 mA cm−2. Additionally, the overpotential (η) is the potential difference between the required potential to achieve a specific current density and the thermodynamic potential of the OER/HER. Typically, this value corresponds to a current density of 10 or −10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3(I)) [54], approximating the current density for a 10% efficiency solar cell device under sunlight [55,56]. Recent efforts have been directed towards the development of electrocatalysts that meet high industrial currents, which is key to the transition from laboratory-scale to industrial-scale applications. Furthermore, the number of active sites is determined by quantifying the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) through CV curves collected at different scan rates. Turnover frequency (TOF) measures the number of converted reactant molecules into target products per catalytically active site, indicating the catalytic activity of metal sites. Faradaic efficiency (FE) refers to the utilization rate of externally supplied electrons in the generation of oxygen/hydrogen [26,57]. CA or CP is used to demonstrate the stability of the electrocatalysts at a specific current or voltage values. When discussing the enhancement of catalysts for water electrolysis, it is equally important to consider the electrolyzer systems themselves, as they play a pivotal role in the overall efficiency of the process [58]. The three primary types of water electrolyzers are proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWE), anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers (AEMWE), and solid oxide electrolysis (SOE) [59]. PEMWEs use a solid polymer electrolyte membrane to conduct protons from the anode to the cathode, where hydrogen is produced. These systems are known for their high efficiency and quick response times, making them suitable for renewable energy integration. Recent advancements have focused on reducing the cost and improving the durability of catalyst coated membranes (CCMs), which play a critical role in the performance and longevity of PEMWE systems [60–63]. Innovations in support materials and iridium oxide deposition techniques are being explored to lower the reliance on precious metals like platinum and iridium, which are typically used as catalysts in these systems. AEMWEs employ an anion exchange membrane to transport hydroxide ions from the cathode to the anode [64,65]. This type of electrolyzer allows for the use of non-precious metal catalysts, potentially reducing costs compared to PEMWEs. However, AEMWEs are still in the developmental stage, with ongoing research aimed at improving membrane stability and ionic conductivity [66]. Despite these challenges, AEMWEs are promising due to their potential for scalability and cost-effectiveness. Current research focuses on optimizing membrane materials and improving system integration to enhance overall performance and durability. SOEs operate at high temperatures, typically between 700 and 1000 °C, using a ceramic electrolyte to conduct oxygen ions from the cathode to the anode [67,68]. This high-temperature operation allows for the direct conversion of steam to hydrogen with high efficiency and offers the potential for co-electrolysis of carbon dioxide and water to produce syngas. The main challenges for SOEs include material stability at these high temperatures and the integration of thermal management systems. Recent studies are exploring novel ceramic materials and advanced system designs to address these issues and improve the viability of SOEs for large-scale hydrogen production. Overall, these technologies each have unique design features, operational characteristics, and performance metrics, contributing to the diverse landscape of water electrolysis aimed at improving the efficiency and feasibility of hydrogen production. Furthermore, some researchers have incorporated stack designs to increase current output for industrial applications [69,70]. However, this introduces several additional considerations. For instance, minimizing parasitic ohmic losses caused by surface contact points between plates is crucial. Moreover, the choice of materials for stack components significantly influences the performance and cost of the electrolyzer. Thus, selecting appropriate materials with high conductivity, durability, and cost-effectiveness is essential to optimize the system's efficiency and economic viability. Additionally, operational conditions and the effects of bubble detachment must be carefully considered. Under industrial conditions, variables such as temperature and solution concentration have a substantial impact on performance [71]. Furthermore, delays in bubble detachment can significantly increase resistance, thereby affecting overall efficiency. It is crucial to optimize these factors to enhance electrolyzer performance and ensure reliable and cost-effective hydrogen production. 3.3 Mechanism study Understanding the reaction mechanism and even the structure reconstruction is of great importance in the design of high-performance MOFs for electrocatalytic water splitting. Given the intricate structure of MOFs, advanced in-situ characterization techniques are necessary to unravel potential reaction mechanisms and identify the true active centers involved in the electrocatalytic process [72]. Since the catalyst is typically in the solid phase while the electrolyte is in the liquid phase, and the electrocatalytic reaction occurs at the interface, different measurements are applicable to investigate different areas (Fig. 4(a) ) [73]. Some research efforts have achieved conversion from feedstocks to high value-added chemicals through the study of interfaces and the study of mechanisms [74,75]. Therefore, a comprehensive certification approach is commonly adopted, encompassing in-situ and ex-situ characterizations along with theoretical calculations. In-situ electrochemical tests typically include FTIR, Raman spectroscopy, mass spectroscopy, XAS, TEM (Figs. 4(B)–(E)) and others [76]. These in-situ characterizations are widely used to monitor the adsorption and transformation of intermediated species during electrocatalytic water splitting, providing real-time spectral information about the physicochemical state of real catalytic active centers and thus facilitating the understanding of the mechanisms. Specifically, FTIR can detect functional group changes, Raman spectroscopy provides insights into molecular vibrations, mass spectroscopy identifies intermediate products, XAS reveals oxidation state changes, and TEM offers structural and morphological information in real-time. However, the role and characteristics of different methods in mechanism analysis are usually different and applied to different situations [77]. Based on spatial, temporal, and spectral resolution, these in-situ techniques can be further elucidated [78]. In-situ spatial resolution techniques, such as optical microscope imaging, fluorescence imaging, and Raman imaging, use visible light and high-energy electron beams to capture real-time structural and morphological changes of the catalysts, which can capture rapid changes in catalytic processes. Besides, the advanced temporal techniques like in-situ electrochemical mass spectrometry and time-resolved ultraviolet-visible absorption spectroscopy provide millisecond to microsecond resolution, allowing observation of intermediate species and reaction kinetics. In-situ spectroscopy techniques, including synchrotron radiation XAS, XRD, XPS, is also a powerful tool to study the electronic, structural, and chemical changes in catalysts. These methods provide detailed information on oxidation states, bond lengths, and electronic structures of MOFs catalysts, essential for understanding fundamental catalytic processes. In addition, theoretical calculations have become crucial for unraveling intricate mechanisms. Enhancing computation and experiments in electrocatalysis involves measuring catalyst intrinsic kinetic behavior, creating accurate models, and establishing clear relationships between calculated reaction energetics and observed rates (Fig. 4(F)) [79]. Most of these theoretical calculations are based on density functional theory (DFT) as shown in Fig. 4(G) [80]. In general, electrocatalytic theoretical calculations encompass several critical aspects. First, charge distribution analysis helps reveal the charge transfer between reactants and the catalyst, which is crucial for the effectiveness of catalytic reactions. By studying the charge distribution on the catalyst surface, scientists can identify regions where charge accumulation occurs, often corresponding to active sites in the reaction, thereby assisting in optimizing catalyst design. Secondly, energy band structure analysis provides insights into the electronic properties of materials. By calculating the band structure, researchers can understand how the catalyst influences the rate of electrocatalytic reactions by modulating its conductivity. The band structure not only determines the efficiency of electron transport within the catalyst but also directly affects the adsorption and dissociation processes of reaction intermediates. Furthermore, density of states (DOS) calculations can reveal the occupancy of electrons in the material at different energy states. Analyzing the DOS curve helps to understand the electronic structure of the material and provides information for optimizing catalytic activity. This information is critical for predicting the catalytic performance of materials, especially when designing new electrocatalysts. Adsorption and desorption free energy step diagrams are another important tool for studying reaction mechanisms. By calculating the free energy changes at each step of the reaction, scientists can evaluate the stability of intermediates, identify the rate-determining steps, and optimize catalyst performance accordingly. This method provides a quantitative basis for improving the efficiency of electrocatalytic reactions. Finally, the d-band center theory has played a significant role in electrocatalysis research. By tuning the d-band center position of transition metal catalysts, researchers can control the adsorption energy of reactants, thereby optimizing the selectivity and activity of the catalytic reaction. This theory has been widely applied to the design of new electrocatalysts, significantly advancing the field. Moreover, with the development of artificial intelligence, machine learning has been increasingly employed in the screening and optimization of electrocatalysts. By training and analyzing large-scale datasets, machine learning models can rapidly predict the catalytic performance of various materials, helping researchers to identify the optimal catalyst combinations and achieve theoretical optimization. This data-driven approach is rapidly transforming the way electrocatalysis research is conducted, offering unprecedented opportunities for innovative catalyst design. In 2019, in-situ synchrotron radiation electrochemical Fourier transform infrared (operando SR-FTIR) spectroscopy technique is established for the first time in China [81]. Using this technique, researchers conduct an in-depth study of the electrocatalytic oxygen reaction process of lattice-strained NiFe-MOF catalysts and observed for the first time that the key intermediate product of the oxygen reaction. *OOH appeared in Fig. 5(A) and bonded directly with the Ni4+ high-valence active centre in the oxygen catalysis process along with the elevation of the valence state of the Ni active centre in Fig. 5(B). It reveals the efficient 4e− oxygen electrocatalytic reaction mechanism of lattice-strained NiFe-MOF catalytic materials at the atomic level. Other researchers measure details of the structural evolution under different temperature treatments by in situ FTIR (Fig. 5(C)) [82]. It shows that the interlayer bond weakens with temperature up to 150 °C, causing a shift in the coordination peak of Cu-O. At 120 °C, no significant change is observed. However, the infrared peak of Cu-O returns to its original position during the subsequent temperature decrease process, suggesting the interlayer structure may be reconstructed if the weakened bonds are not removed. Additionally, the structural transition of MOF materials is investigated by electrochemical in situ monitoring of the characteristic peaks of Raman spectra of Ni0.9Fe0.1-MOF and Ni-MOF at different voltages during electrocatalysis (Fig. 5(D)) [83]. Although the Ni(OH)2/NiOOH structural transition is observed in both Ni0.9Fe0.1-MOF and Ni-MOF, Fe doping significantly reduces the potential of Ni0.9Fe0.1-MOF for the transition from Ni(OH)2 to NiOOH during electrocatalysis (Ni2+ → Ni3+/Ni4+). Furthermore, NiCo-MOF-74 were analysed in detail for nickel oxidation and structural transformation under operational conditions using operando XAS (Fig. 5(E)) [18]. It was concluded that the dynamically biphasic reconstruction occurs at the local metal nodes inside the pores during the OER, rather than as decomposition of MOF crystal structures. Researchers suggest that Ni0.5Co0.5OOH0.75, with abundant oxygen vacancies and high oxidation states, forms in situ and is responsible for the high OER activity observed. As shown in Fig. 5(F), the wavelet transform (WT) also shows the in-situ reconfiguration of MOFs from hydroxide analogue to hydroxyl oxide analogue during electrocatalysis. Through these detailed characterizations, researchers can better understand the mechanisms driving electrocatalytic water splitting, thereby informing the design and optimization of high-performance MOFs for sustainable energy applications. 4 Regulation strategies Pristine MOFs, known for their lack of additional heat treatment or conversion, have become increasingly popular in recent years for electrocatalytic water splitting applications. The design and synthesis of pristine MOFNSs are intricately linked to the methods employed in their creation. As a matter of common knowledge, forces such as hydrogen bonding, van der Waals force and π-π stacking are much weaker than covalent bonds and coordination bonds. Leveraging this knowledge, researchers use external forces to disrupt these weaker interplanar forces, facilitating the formation of MOFNSs. A variety of top-down synthesis methods have been developed to achieve this, including sonication exfoliation [84], ball milling [85], chemical exfoliation [86,87], and intercalation synthesis [88], all of which effectively transform bulk MOFs into 2D layers. Conversely, bottom-up synthesis employs metal ions and ligands to build two-dimensional structures through selective chemical reactions. This method controls MOF growth by inhibiting it in one direction while promoting it in the other two, leading to the development of various synthesis techniques such as ultrasonic synthesis [26], interfacial synthesis [22], surfactant-assisted synthesis [89], and sacrificial template synthesis [90]. Significant emphasis is placed on the precise selection and optimization of metal sites and organic ligands at an atomic level, a crucial approach for modulating the electrocatalytic properties of pristine MOFNSs. Moreover, the incorporation of defect engineering and composite materials plays a vital role in this context. Additional design strategies are explored towards the document's end to address any remaining gaps in the methodologies. 4.1 Metal species control Different metal nodes play a pivotal role in the MOF crystal structure (Fig. 6(A) ) [91]. The selection of the metal center is crucial because it often acts as the active site in most MOFNSs. Many of these metal ions possess unsaturated coordination sites on the surface of MOFNSs, which are key for facilitating rapid mass and charge transfer. Transition metal compounds, including Ni, Co, and Fe, serve as non-precious metal electrocatalysts and are widely utilized for the electrocatalytic decomposition of water. Their use is favored due to their abundant availability and cost-effectiveness. When choosing metal ions for MOF synthesis, it is essential to consider both their catalytic activity and stability. According to the Hard-Soft-Acid-Base (HSAB) theory, interactions are stronger between matching pairs of hard Lewis acids and bases or soft Lewis acids and bases, compared to mismatches between hard and soft categories. Therefore, to enhance MOF stability, researchers often construct frameworks using either carboxylic acid-based ligands (hard Lewis bases) with high-valent metal ions (hard Lewis acids), or azo-based ligands (soft Lewis bases) with low-valent transition metal ions (soft Lewis acids) as shown in Fig. 6(B) [92]. Moreover, the potential of bimetallic or polymetallic MOFs should not be overlooked. The interactions between different metals can lead to charge attraction or repulsion, which significantly influences the electrocatalytic activity of MOFNSs. This complex interplay requires careful consideration to optimize the functionality of the MOFs. Early research on single-metal MOFNSs laid the groundwork for the study of polymetallic MOFNSs. Some monometallic MOFs, such as Co-MOFs, Ni-MOFs, Cu-MOFs, have witnessed rapid and significant development in the field of electrocatalysis. For instance, the researchers adopted a one-step facile hydrothermal method to synthesize a two-dimensional Co-MOF by using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a surface directing agent as depicted in Fig. 7(A) [89]. This process yielded a nanosheet approximately 2 nm thick, demonstrating high catalytic activity with a low onset potential. As illustrated in Fig. 7(B), this Co-MOF comprises three metal coordination layers with a theoretical monolith thickness of 1.941 nm, as confirmed by AFM measurements. The enhanced OER activity of 2D Co-MOF can be attributed to the accessible unsaturated Co2+ centres which facilitate the interaction with OH− ions. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 7(C), a shift in the chemical peaks towards higher binding energies in the ultrathin 2D Co-MOF compared to its bulk counterpart suggests oxidation of Co(II) to Co(III), enhancing its catalytic performance. Another group achieved the synthesis of large-area and self-supporting 2D supramolecular polymer (2DSP) sheets using the Langmuir-Blodgett method at an air/water interface (Fig. 7(D)) [93]. These 2DSPs, composed of triphenylene-fused nickel bis(dithiolene) complexes, demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic activity for hydrogen generation from water. From the AFM results as showed in Fig. 7(E), the 2DSPs are only 0.7–0.9 nm, which shows that only a single layer of the sheet is available. The chemical makeup of these THTNi 2DSP sheets was influenced by the addition of Ni salts, leading to polymerization. The deconvolution of the S 2p signal yielded four sets of doublets, as seen in Fig. 7(F), indicating effective complexation between Ni2+ ions and thiol groups, with a Ni/S ratio of 1:4.8 and a slightly higher sulphur content. The oxidation states of sulphur, specifically S-O3 and S-O4, suggest partial oxidation of the thiol groups. Similarly, Marinescu et al. [25] successfully integrated dithiocobaltocene catalysts onto metal-organic surfaces, producing highly active electrocatalytic cathode materials for hydrogen generation from water (Fig. 7(G)). In addition, Ni-MOF nanosheet arrays for water oxidation were successfully synthesized by hydrothermal treatment [94]. In another research, Louie and colleagues synthesized few-layered metal-organic networks (MONs) using hexaaminobenzene (HAB) as a linker and M(acac)2 (M = Ni, Cu, Co, acac = acetylacetonate) as metal sources (Fig. 7(H)) [95]. AFM measurements indicated similar thicknesses of 8–10 monolayers, though single-layer MONs could not be fabricated due to strong π–π stacking interactions. Bu and colleagues introduced two novel Co MOFs, CTGU-5 and CTGU-6, with distinct coordination and lattice patterns in 2D and 3D structures (Fig. 7(I)) [96]. This Co-MOF is known as one of the best MOFNSs for its optimal HER catalytic performance in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4, requiring only an onset potential of 18 mV and an overpotential of 44 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2, with a low Tafel slope of 45 mV dec−1. A common strategy to optimize the catalytic performance of pristine MOFNSs is the introduction of heterometals to construct bimetallic MOFNSs. These can be synthesized relatively easily either through one-pot synthesis using mixtures of different metals or by post-synthetic ion-exchange methods, where monometallic MOFs are immersed in concentrated solutions of various metal ions [97]. As illustrated in Fig. 8(A) , the researchers successfully prepare a series of bimetallic ultrathin MOFNSs using a straightforward sonication method [26]. With a thickness of only about 3 nm, as shown in Fig. 8(B), these UMOFNs are utilized as electrocatalysts for OER in alkaline media, outperforming both bulk MOFs and commercial RuO2. Meanwhile, coupling DFT calculations and XPS measurements, it is concluded that the π-donation via Co-O can be strengthened by the electron-electron repulsion between O2− and Ni2+, which triggers partial charge transfer from Ni2+ to Co2+, as depicted in Fig. 8(C). Furthermore, a 2D oxide sacrificial method is reported to prepare ultrathin FeCo MOF-74 nanosheets with a thickness of only 2.6 nm (Fig. 8(D)) [90]. This process involves the controlled leaching of metal ions from the metal-organic nanosheets (M-ONS) using acidic ligand solutions under hydrothermal conditions, enhancing the concentration of metal ions near the surface and thus directing the MOF crystals’ growth predominantly in two dimensions. XRD patterns confirm that the MOF crystals preferentially grow along the [300] direction during the first 8 hours of the reaction, promoting the oriented development of MOF-74 nanosheets. Subsequently, Zhou et al. [98] revealed that the OER activity of bimetallic Ni-M-MOF (M = Fe, Co, Cu, Mn, and Zn) can be systematically regulated by the substitution of Ni atoms with other transition metal species M in Ni-MOF (Fig. 8(E)). Specifically, the activity is arranged in a decreasing sequence of NiFe-MOF > NiCo-MOF > NiCu-MOF > NiMn-MOF > NiZn-MOF, which is in agreement with the predictions of DFT calculations. Impressively, the best bimetallic NiFe-MOF requires only 215 and 297 mV overpotentials to obtain current densities of 10 and 500 mA cm−2, respectively. Polymetallic MOFNSs demonstrate significantly more complex synergistic effects between metal nodes compared to their bimetallic counterparts. Introducing catalytically active metal nodes into MOFs through the component design of metal nodes is a straightforward yet effective strategy. In polymetallic MOFNSs, the primary modifications in electrocatalytic activity stem from interactions involving charge and energy bands among the metals. An illustration of this is the fabrication of ultrathin and highly curved two-dimensional nanosheets of FeCoNi trimetallic-organic frameworks (FeCoNi-MOFs) [99], which have a thickness of approximately 1.5 nm, as shown in Fig. 9(A) . Enhancements in the Fermi energy level, driven by multiple heterogeneous interfaces and the introduction of oxygen vacancies, facilitate the pre-oxidation of low-valent metals and the reconstruction/deprotonation of the intermediate metal, OOH. This process significantly improves electron transport efficiency. Fig. 9(B) depicts FeCo2Ni-MOF-74 with a rich oxygen vacancy (Ovac) structure and OER pathway, involving four adsorption/desorption steps and three intermediates. The DOS of optimized models in Fig. 9(C) is critical for understanding the effects of inner doping and defects in the catalyst. The calculated d-band centre levels of Fe-MOF-74, Co2Ni-MOF-74, FeCo2Ni-MOF-74, and FeCo2Ni-MOF-74-Ovac have been confirmed, indicating variations in their electronic structures. In a similar research, Li et al. [100] presents a convenient microwave-assisted synthesis of NiCoFe-based trimetallic MOF nanosheets, enabling rapid synthesis and activation of MOF for OER, as illustrated in Fig. 9(D). The prepared Ni4Co4Fe2-MOF nanosheets exhibit excellent OER activity and electrochemical stability, delivering a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 243 mV and a Tafel slope of just 48.1 mV dec−1. This work not only showcases a rapid synthesis technique for MOF nanosheets but also highlights an effective method to tune the electronic structure of MOFs for enhanced electrocatalytic performance. In addition, the integration of multiple metals to form high-entropy materials is a highly effective strategy for attaining extraordinary physicochemical and electrocatalytic properties. High entropy (HE) MOFs containing five metals, nickel, cobalt, iron, zinc and molybdenum, are synthesized using a mild solvent thermal method by Xu and his colleagues (Fig. 9(E)) [101]. These HE-MOFs exhibit a 2D array structure, which significantly enhanced electrical conductivity and facilitating mass transport of reactants, intermediates, and products. Notably, the HE-MOFs have a good crystallinity with a lattice spacing of 1.23 nm, and their 2D structure is ultrathin as depicted in HRTEM images in Fig. 9(F) and confirmed to be 1.8 nm thick in AFM images shown in Fig. 9(G). Mechanistic investigations revealed that MO6/MOOH (M = metals) intermediates as the active centres, and the synergistic effects of the different metals contributed to increase entropy. Consequently, as a result in Fig. 9(H), the electrocatalyst demonstrated outstanding activity for OER with a low overpotential of 254 mV to achieve a current density of 50 mA cm−2, along with long-term stability for up to 100 h. In a similar vein, Zhao et al. [102] employed a solution-phase method at ambient temperature to synthesize a HE-MOF with five nearly-equimolar components. Notably, this HE-MOF exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity for OER in an alkaline system when utilized as an electrocatalyst. This innovative approach presents a versatile and effective means of expanding the range of high-entropy materials and catalysts available for enhancing the efficiency of electrochemical water splitting. Alternatively, 2D conductive MOF array architectures were presented using a novel approach involving a one-step dissolution-recrystallization synthetic procedure in 2021 [103]. This technique has successfully produced a series of 2D conducting MOF arrays, including unary (Ni and Fe), binary (NiFe, NiCo, NiV, NiNb and NiTa), ternary (NiFeZn and NiNbZn), quaternary (NiCoFeZn) and quinary (NiCoFeMnZn)-MOFs, thus confirming the universal adaptability of this approach under various experimental conditions. These architectures provide numerous benefits for electrocatalytic reactions, including metallic conductivity, hierarchical porosity, and vertically aligned array structures. However, research on high-entropy MOF materials is still in its nascent stages, necessitating further experimental and theoretical studies to uncover their fundamental properties and potential. As the field advances, there are many more studies on the metal-centre controlled synthesis and modification of MOFNSs, and the specific metal modulation mechanisms are being increasingly refined. In conclusion, the intricate interplay of metal nodes within the structure of MOFNSs significantly enhances their performance in electrocatalytic applications. The selection of appropriate metal centres, influenced by factors such as electron configuration and coordination environment, is pivotal in optimizing the electrocatalytic efficiency and stability of MOFNSs. By employing strategies such as the HSAB theory for ligand-metal interactions and the integration of polymetallic systems, researchers can significantly enhance 2D MOF functionalities. The advances in synthesizing bimetallic and polymetallic MOFNSs have led to notable improvements in mass and charge transfer rates, demonstrating the potential for these materials in sustainable energy applications, particularly in water splitting. The exploration of HE-MOFs offers a promising avenue for further enhancing the physicochemical properties and performance of catalytic materials. The creation of MOFNSs with a diverse array of metal ions may lead to materials that exhibit superior stability and catalytic activity due to the synergistic effects of multiple metal environments. Continued research into the design, synthesis, and application of multifunctional 2D MOF structures will be essential in harnessing their full potential, particularly for energy conversion technologies. As the field progresses, understanding the specific roles and interactions of different metal centres within MOFNSs will be crucial for developing next-generation materials tailored for specific catalytic processes. 4.2 Ligand design Modifying the chemical composition of organic ligands also plays a crucial role in tuning the properties of MOF electrocatalysts. By incorporating diverse functional group into the organic ligand, electron donor groups can enhance the energy of the excited state in the ligand, while electron-withdrawing groups can have the opposite effect [104]. Additionally, the length of the ligand significantly influences the morphology and pore size of the MOFs, which consequently affects their electrocatalytic performance. The selection of ligands is a vital in determining both the structure and stability of MOFs. Apart from considering the HSAB theory mentioned in the previous section, topology, porosity, hydrophobicity, and π-π stacking of linkers all affect stability [105]. Depending on the chosen linker, the topology and other characteristics of MOFs can vary for a given metal ion. Researchers have explored the synergistic modulation of electrocatalytic activity at Co sites in two-dimensional Co-MOFs synthesized with nine different ligands, featuring various combinations of organic backbones and functional groups (Fig. 10(A) ) [106]. Planar conjugated structures such as benzene, triphenylene, and trinaphthalene enhance electrical conductivity through their delocalized π-electrons, facilitating charge transport. These structures, with overlapping p-orbitals on neighboring atoms, provide efficient pathways for electron transfer, making them ideal for materials designed to improve electrical conductivity. As depicted in Fig. 10(B), Co sites anchored by different ligands exhibit variations in Bader charge transfer, magnetic moments, and d-band centers. Co sites coordinated by oxygen atoms transfer more electrons compared to those coordinated by nitrogen or sulfur atoms when the organic ligand backbones are identical. The magnetic moments of Co sites across nine different Co-MOFs follow a similar trend, with Co-2O exhibiting the largest magnetic moment (1.12 μB), which enhances the spin polarization of the metal active site and boosts its electrocatalytic activity. The longer organic ligand backbones accept more electrons from the Co site when the functional groups are consistent. This modulation affects the interaction between the active site and key reaction intermediates, thereby improving the overall catalytic performance. Likewise, regulation of ligands by halogenated elements is also reported [107]. Researchers propose a specialized electrocatalyst for FeNi-MOFs by engineering the ligands to modulate the coordination environment of the metal active center using fluorine, chlorine, and bromine, as shown in Fig. 10(C). Modifications by bromine, chlorine, and fluorine resulted in a closer alignment of Ni-3d energy band center to Fermi level, as demonstrated in Fig. 10(D). XANEs of four catalysts in Fig. 10(E) reveal energy shifts due to coordination environments and subtle shifts in valence states, indicating successful modulation of the metal sites with halogen atoms. Similarly, modified organic ligands with nitrogen or oxygen atoms [108], or doping multifunctional ligands [109], can improve the electrocatalytic activity of MOFs by chelating metal sites through coordination bonds within metal nodes or exposing the high density of active sites. Furthermore, ultrathin 2D nickel-based MOF nanosheets, with a thickness of only 2 nm, are successfully synthesized using a ligand-assisted controlled growth strategy [110]. This approach involves controlled leaching of Ni2+ from NiO nanowire arrays, which increases the concentration of Ni2+ near the surface, thereby restricting MOF crystal growth into 2D nanosheet structures. As depicted in Fig. 10(F), Ni-MOF nanosheets with controllable thickness can be prepared through corrosion-dissolution-coordination, utilizing terephthalic acid and 3,5-bis (1-imidazoly) pyridine for modulation. Another new coordination modulation method is developed to regulate the facet information of NiFe-MOFs, facilitating their 2D morphological construction [111]. The researchers employed acetate ions as multifunctional modulators to synthesize a series of 2D NiFe-MOFNSs with varying degrees of (001) crystal facet exposure. This process, driven by a high concentration of acetate ions, promotes the self-assembly of MOF nanoflakes into a kinetically favourable hierarchical morphology. This synthetic procedure allows for the preparation of Ni-, Co-, Cu-, Zn-based MOFNSs and corresponding bimetal MOFs. Analogously, Huang et al. [82] synthesized a 3D pillared-layer MOF with selective removal of pillars, resulting in ultrathin (2 nm) MOF with high OER activities. The length of the ligand linker is an important variable that affects mass transfer and charge transfer within MOFs. Specifically, the size of the ligand can alter key structural features of MOFs, such as layer spacing and porous structure, which in turn influences the catalytic performance [112]. For example, the larger linker endowed the conductive MOF with a favourable in-plane mesoporous structure for mass transport [113]. Recent research discovers a correlation between the choice of the linker, the activation and aging process, which ultimately affects the performance of Ni-MOF-derived nickel-hydroxide catalysts over time, particularly concerning the ratio of α-Ni(OH)2 to β-Ni(OH)2 [114], as outlined in the Fig. 10(G). Specifically, they synthesized different Ni-MOFs with the general formula [Ni2(OH)2 L] (1, L = 1,4-BDC; 2, L = 2,6-napthalenedicarboxylate (NDC); 3, L = biphenyl-4,4′-di- carboxylate (BPDC) and 4, L = p-terphenyl-4,4″-dicarboxylate (TPDC)). They reflected the difference in interlayer distance with increasing joint length in the XRD and confirmed that the Ni centres are expected to have similar coordination environments in the Ni K-edge XAS. In a comparable manner, Yuan et al. [115] developed a series of metal hydroxide-organic frameworks (MHOFs) that integrate molecular catalysts with highly tuneable electronic structures and metal oxides, enhancing stability under alkaline OER conditions. The stability of these MHOFs is governed by π-stacking interactions between linkers connecting adjacent hydroxide layers. This work also reflects the fact that different length ligand linkers present different π-π stacking strengths, which in turn affects their activity or stability. In summary, the strategic modification of organic ligands significantly influences the properties of MOFNSs and enhances their utility in electrocatalysis. By integrating diverse functional groups and adjusting ligand lengths, researchers can tailor the electronic properties and morphological features of MOFs, thereby optimizing their performance in various catalytic processes. The synthesis of MOFNSs, utilizing controlled growth techniques, exemplifies the potential for precision in creating materials with desired thickness and functional capabilities. Additionally, the introduction of varying ligand types demonstrates a sophisticated method of modulating the electronic environment at the metal sites, crucial for improving the catalytic efficiency and stability. Further research in this field should focus on developing a deeper understanding of the interaction mechanisms between ligands and metal sites under operational conditions. The exploration of new ligand frameworks with exceptional electron-donating or electron-withdrawing capabilities could provide insights into the manipulation of electronic properties and catalytic activity. Moreover, expanding the types of metals integrated into these frameworks may lead to the discovery of novel catalytic materials with unique properties. As MOFs continue to emerge as versatile materials in catalysis, their potential applications in energy conversion, storage, and environmental remediation are expected to expand, driving further innovation in materials science and engineering. 4.3 Defect engineering In the crystal structure of MOFNSs, atoms can deviate from their ideal positions to form defects, which significantly impact physical and chemical properties [116]. Vacancies formed by thermal diffusion and external fields can efficiently alter the local electronic structure and coordination environment in MOFNSs, resulting in localized electronic states, band gap modifications, and reduced coordination numbers. Subsequently, such defects can alter electronic and geometric properties of metal active sites, thus regulating the adsorption capacity of reaction species [117]. The introduction of defects in MOFs can lead to a redistribution of electron configurations, potentially creating defective conducting channels that enhance electrocatalytic activity [118]. Therefore, understanding these mechanisms and their impacts is crucial for designing materials with tailored properties for specific applications. Common defect engineering strategies in MOFNSs include metal deletion, lattice distortion, and the breaking and reforming of bonds, which collectively increase the number of active sites [119]. It must be acknowledged that while defects can enhance functionality, they might also lead to structural collapse in some cases. Moreover, a high density of defects could potentially reduce electrical conductivity. Despite these challenges, the field requires a more systematic investigation to fully understand the implications of defects in MOFNSs and their effect on electrocatalytic performance. Such studies are crucial for advancing the application of defect engineering in optimizing material properties for specific technological applications. Lattice distortion represents a special type of defect in MOFNSs. For instance, lattice-strained transition metal MOF materials are developed as highly active bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts [77]. A pristine NiFe MOF nanosheet array was synthesized using a low-temperature hydrothermal method, with each sheet measuring approximately 20 nm in thickness. The fringe lattice parameter of the nanosheet was initially determined to be 11.6 Å, corresponding to an interlayer spacing typical of naphthalene-based MOFs with transition metal nodes. Post different ultraviolet treatment durations, the interlayer space of the lattice-strained NiFe MOF expanded to 11.8, 12.0, and 12.1 Å, indicating lattice expansion ratios of 1.7%, 3.6%, and 4.3% respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 11(A) . The Fourier transform of EXAFS at the Ni K-edge and their fitting results are presented in Fig. 11(B). The dominant peak at 1.6 Å corresponds to the nearest shell coordination of the metal-oxygen (M–O) bond, while weak peaks at 2.8 and 3.1 Å indicate higher shell contribution of M–O/C and M–M bonds. With increasing lattice strain, the nearest M–O bond peak shifts to a lower R-value, while the third M–M bond peak moves to a higher R-value. Creating oxygen vacancies to create defects is another option by adding a reducing agent in the material. For instance, MOFs with defective Co–O bonds and amorphous Co-B species are created by NaBH4 treating, resulting in disordered electronic configurations and modulating OER performance [118], as depicted in Fig. 11(C). The introduction of a defective Co–O bond increased DOS near the Fermi level as shown in Fig. 11(D), confirming enhanced carrier density and improved conductivity. Charge density mapping highlighted remarkable electronic delocalization around the defect sites (VO), as presented in Fig. 11(E). This green, convenient, safe, and cost-effective strategy for introducing defects in MOFs opens up exciting possibilities for investigating high-efficiency electrocatalysts in energy conversion and expanding our understanding of defect design and mechanism studies. Alternatively, defects can also be engineered through acid or base etching methods. For instance, Zhou et al. [119] develop a defect-rich nanosheet array (D-Ni-MOF NSA) of a Ni(II)-based MOF using an alkali-etched strategy, which involved the partial breakdown of NiO bonds by the intrusion of KOH. This process introduced open unsaturated Ni sites and extra-framework K cations, tailoring electrocatalytic properties for overall water splitting. The resulting D-Ni-MOF||D-Ni-MOF electrolyte cell exhibited a lower and stable voltage of 1.50 V at 10 mA cm−2 in an alkaline medium (Fig. 11(F)). The D-Ni-MOF NSA exhibits enhanced conductivity due to increased basicity around the Ni centre and the introduction of extra-framework K cations. Open metal sites and oxygen vacancies facilitated the reduction of energy barriers in OER and HER, while K serves as conduction electrons and the increased basicity around the Ni centre promotes fast charge transfer. This is a novel alkali-etched strategy used to fabricate defect-rich ultrathin Ni(II)-MOF nanosheet arrays, resulting in high electrocatalytic activity and durability. Analogously, a facile Argon plasma treatment introduces defects in MOF nanosheets while maintaining their morphology [120]. The generated coordinatively unsaturated metal sites improve intrinsic catalytic activity, while formed mesopores facilitate mass transport. The plasma-etched MOF nanosheets exhibit excellent OER performance, displaying an ultralow overpotential of 213 mV at a current density of 50 mA cm−2. Moreover, missing-linker or missing-metal ion deletion is a common method for constructing defects. A universal strategy is reported to enhance the OER activity of MOFs by incorporating missing linkers like carboxyferrocene (Fig. 11(G)) [121]. This effectively regulates the electronic structure of Co-BDC, optimizing adsorption strength and band gap. This strategy confirms the enhanced catalytic activity of MOFs with missing linkers and presents a new way to regulate their electronic structure, potentially making them high-efficiency electrocatalysts for future applications. Similarly, Sun et al. [50] incorporated Fe3+ or ATA into Ni-BDC can introduce inhomogeneous lattice strain, weakening coordination bonds. This selectively cleaves the MOFs, generating coordinatively unsaturated metal sites and hierarchical porous structures. In conclusion, the incorporation of structural defects in MOFNSs provides a strategic pathway to enhance their electrocatalytic performance. Defect engineering, through methods such as metal deletion, lattice distortion, and bond reformation, introduces variations in the electron configuration and geometric structure of MOFNSs. These modifications facilitate the creation of active sites and improve electron mobility, crucial for optimizing electrocatalytic activities. Although excessive defects can compromise structural integrity and conductivity, a controlled introduction of defects can significantly amplify catalytic efficiency. Future research in this domain should focus on meticulously balancing the introduction of defects to optimize electrocatalytic performance without compromising the structural stability of MOFs. Advanced characterization techniques will be vital in identifying the optimal types and concentrations of defects. Moreover, computational modelling and simulation could play a pivotal role in predicting the effects of these defects on electronic properties and catalytic behaviour, guiding experimental approaches. Ultimately, enhancing the understanding of defect dynamics in MOFNSs will enable the development of more efficient and durable electrocatalysts, contributing to advancements in energy conversion technologies such as water splitting. The exploration of defect engineering in MOFNSs thus holds substantial promise for the advancement of catalysis and materials science, paving the way for the development of next-generation materials optimized for a range of energy and environmental applications. 4.4 Composite materials Heterostructure MOF-on-MOF composites, which involve assembling multiple homogeneous or heterogeneous MOFs with distinct structures and morphologies, are increasingly recognized in chemistry and materials science. These composites exhibit unrivaled tunability, hierarchical nanostructure, synergistic effects, and enhanced performance. Variations in the a, b, and c lattice parameters can induce structural changes, enabling the creation of composite materials with diverse growth techniques for subsequent MOFs derived from an initial MOF framework [122]. For instance, Fischer et al. [123] demonstrated the first well-oriented MOF-on-MOF film through layer-by-layer growth in 2014. The research work utilized a gold-modified quartz crystal microbalance as a substrate for growing of [Cu2ndc2dabco] and [Cu3btc2] films via a liquid-phase heteroepitaxial growth approach. The successful fabrication of a MOF-on-MOF film was confirmed by the identification of an interface between the [Cu2ndc2dabco] layer and subsequent growth of HKUST-1. Additionally, MOF multilayer systems have been also created hierarchically with varying nanoscale pores size (Fig. 12(A) ) [124]. They achieved large lattice constant mismatches at MOF-MOF heterojunctions using a specific liquid-phase epitaxy process. They demonstrated multiheteroepitaxy for the isoreticular SURMOF-2 series, achieving highly crystalline, oriented multilayers despite 20% lattice mismatches. Fascinatingly, unique MOF hybrid rings and plates are prepared from ZIF-L starting materials by controlling three processes: growth (G), etching (E), and transformation (T), as detailed in Fig. 12(B) [125]. The GET process yielded ZIF-8@ZIF-67 (Co, Zn) and ZIF-8@ZIF-8 rings, while the GT process yielded ZIF-8@ZIF-67 plates. Electron microscopy and XRD and elemental analysis confirmed the structural transformation and MOF-on-MOF growth. By meticulously controlling these processes, well-defined atypical hybrid MOFs are prepared. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the growth techniques described is not confined to two-dimensional exclusively. For instance, Researchers have successfully achieved the selective epitaxial growth of oriented multilevel MOF heterostructures through careful modulation of growth conditions and surface properties, facilitating the precise alignment and arrangement of various MOF layers [126]. Although these materials are not widely used for electrocatalytic decomposition of water, they provide ideas for the design of this novel catalyst. Moreover, there are research studies exploring MOFs combined with the other MOFs. One such example is that an in-situ two-step solvothermal process was rationally designed for the fabrication of MOF-(74+274)@NFF, core-shell-like self-supporting MOF hybrids grown on NiFe alloy foam [127]. The XPS and XAS results reveal that the electron distribution can be precisely regulated through partial charge transfer between the MOF-274 and MOF-74 upon hybridization. The results from these investigations highlight a substantial improvement in catalytic activity, demonstrating the potential of MOF-on-MOF composites in electrocatalysis. Furthermore, the integration of MOF nanosheets with guest materials has recently been identified as an effective method to enhance both conductivity and stability. The synthesis of heterostructures in 2D MOF materials has emerged as a promising strategy to boost electrocatalytic activity while preserving the integrity of the original structure and morphology. The incorporation of diverse functional materials within the MOFNSs allows for synergistic interactions and optimization of catalytic performance. The incorporation of heterostructures in MOFNSs brings forth additional active sites, promote charge transfer, as well as modify the electronic and surface properties, ultimately leading to improved electrocatalytic activity for various reactions including water splitting. The successful synthesis of these heterostructures in MOFNSs marks a significant step towards the design and development of highly efficient electrocatalysts with superior performance and stability. Ongoing research in this field focuses on refining synthesis strategies and deepening our understanding of the mechanisms that underpin this enhanced electrocatalytic activity. These endeavors are ultimately expected to advance the practical application of 2D MOF heterostructures in various energy conversion and storage technologies, thereby contributing to the development of sustainable and clean energy solutions. For instance, MOFNSs composite nanosheets based on Ni-BDC are developed, which exhibit excellent performance in HER electrocatalysis [128], (Fig. 12(C)). Notably, the catalytic activity of FePc@Ni-MOF significantly surpasses that of FePc, Ni-MOF, and FePc@bulk-MOF, shedding new light on the potential of MOF-based nanosheet composites. Comparably, a novel hierarchical hetero-electrocatalyst comprising Ni3S2@2D Co MOF is synthesized through the crystallization of cobalt MOFs on carbon paper and in-situ electrodeposition of Ni3S2 nanosheets (Fig. 12(D)) [129]. This catalyst exhibited exceptional HER activity with a low overpotential of 140 mV at a current density of −10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 90.3 mV dec−1. Interestingly, when compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst, Ni3S2@2D Co-MOF/CP demonstrates a lower overpotential (395 mV) at a high current density (>130 mA cm−2). The remarkable efficiency and stability of Ni3S2@2D Co-MOF/CP in HER can be attributed to the unique structure of nickel sulfide honeycomb nanosheets grown on MOFNSs. This structure enhances charge transfer and hydrogen evolution, while the electron-rich surface of nickel sulfide reduces the adsorption of hydrogen intermediates and lowers the energy barrier for hydrogen generation. Correspondingly, 2D Co-BDC/MoS2 hybrid nanosheets are created using a sonication-assisted solution strategy (Fig. 12(E)) [130]. The introduction of Co-BDC induces a partial phase transfer from 2H-MoS2 to 1T-MoS2, which activates the inert basal plane, improving HER activity. Analogously, Li et al. [131] develop a synthetic approach to obtain Co-MOF nanosheets via a hydrothermal process. Subsequently, they achieve the formation of 2D CoP/Co-MOF heterostructure nanosheets through low-temperature phosphorylation on a carbon paper substrate. Importantly, the resulting CoP/Co-MOF heterostructures retained the advantageous 2D nanosheet structure of the pristine Co-MOF. The interaction between the 2D CoP nanosheets and 2D Co-MOF nanosheets, facilitated by electrostatic forces, played a critical role in modulating the surface chemistry of the electrocatalysts. The CoP/Co-MOF heterostructures effectively merged the superior electrical conductivity and porosity of Co-based nanoparticles with the dispersed active sites characteristic of the original MOF. These heterostructures combine the superior electrical conductivity and porosity of Co-based nanoparticles with the dispersed active sites of the original MOF, significantly boosting catalytic activity. Moreover, a single-atom strategy is employed to construct excellent HER electrocatalyst (NiRu0.13-BDC) using atomically dispersed ruthenium in MOFNSs (Fig. 12(F)) [132]. This catalyst exhibits excellent hydrogen evolution activity across all pH levels, with a low overpotential and performance comparable to commercial Pt/C. The introduction of Ru single-atom can effectively modulate the electronic structure of the metal center in the MOF, optimizing binding strength for H2O and H*, enhancing overall HER performance. This method represents a highly efficient approach for catalyst design, promising significant advancements in the field of electrocatalysis. Furthermore, there are various MOFs that, despite not being intrinsically two-dimensional, can manifest the catalytic benefits associated with the two-dimensional nature when incorporated with other 2D materials. For instance, Huang et al. [133]. have made significant advancements in the field of 2D nanomaterials by successfully coating diverse nanosheets, including MoS2, graphene oxide (GO), and reduced graphene oxide (rGO), as well as their hybrids with metal nanoparticles (Pt-GO, Pt-rGO, and Pt-MoS2) using ZIF-8. This novel approach of creating 2D core-shell structures, with the functional 2D materials serving as the core and the MOFs acting as the shell, offers tremendous potential in catalysis, energy storage and conversion, as well as information storage devices. The integration of 2D nanomaterials with MOFs into core-shell structures offers several advantages. It combines the distinct properties of different materials, such as the exceptional conductivity of graphene-based materials and the catalytic activity of metal nanoparticles. Additionally, the MOF shell provides excellent stability, controlled porosity, and an increased surface area, all of which are advantageous for catalytic applications. By precisely controlling the coating process and manipulating the composition and morphology of the core-shell structures, researchers can tailor the properties and performance of these materials for specific applications. In short, 2D MOF composite materials have shown great potential in electrocatalytic water splitting. These composites, formed by integrating MOFNSs with various functional materials, offer unique advantages, including large surface area, tunable pore structure, and versatile chemical compositions. They provide an ideal platform for efficient and stable electrocatalysis. Researchers have made significant progress in developing 2D MOF composite materials for water electrolysis, aiming to address the challenges of high overpotential, sluggish reaction kinetics, and limited active sites. These composite materials have demonstrated remarkable electrocatalytic performance due to the synergistic effect between the MOFNSs and functional materials. The 2D MOF component provides a stable framework for anchoring active species and enhancing electron transport, while the functional materials contribute to improved catalytic activity and charge transfer. By carefully engineering the composition and structure of 2D MOF composites, researchers have achieved enhanced water splitting efficiency, reduced energy consumption, and prolonged catalyst lifetime. 4.5 Other emerging methods In addition to the main design options mentioned above, there are various other strategies that can be used to design MOFNSs to improve electrocatalytic performance. Firstly, expanding the active sites is a good choice. One way to enhance the electrocatalytic water decomposition reaction is to increase the number of active sites on the catalyst surface. For instance, researchers explore the use of a new conjugated ligand called hexaiminohexaazatrinaphthalene (HAHATN) [113]. This ligand is employed to construct bimetallic sited conductive MOFs (M23(M13·HAHATN)2) with an additional M-N2 moiety. DFT calculations reveal that the 2D conjugated framework of the MOFs results in high electrical conductivity, a narrow bandgap (0.19 eV) for efficient electron transfer, and a favorable in-plane porous structure (2.7 nm) for effective mass transfer. Furthermore, the metal atom at the extra M-N2 moiety exhibits a higher unsaturation degree compared to the metal atom at the M-N4 linkage, leading to a stronger ability to donate electrons and enhance electroactivity. These characteristics make the new conductive MOFs highly electroactive for HER catalysis.
