Among the various (M23(M13·HAHATN)2) MOFs studied, the Ni3(Ni3·HAHATN)2 nanosheets with the optimal structure demonstrate a small overpotential of 115 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a low Tafel slope of (45.6 mV dec−1), and promising electrocatalytic stability for HER. Overall, this work presents an effective strategy for designing conductive MOFs with favorable structures for electrocatalysis. The use of the new conjugated ligand and the incorporation of an extra metallic center contribute to the enhanced electroactivity of the MOFs for HER. This research provides valuable insights for the development of efficient and stable electrocatalysts based on MOFs. Secondly, tuning the electronic structure is another approach. Fine-tuning the electronic structure of a catalyst can optimize electron transport and catalytic activity. This can be achieved by adjusting the valence, electron affinity and hybridized chemical bonding of the catalyst to improve the performance of electrocatalytic water decomposition reactions. Zhu et al. [134] coated a molecule with π-orbital conjugation on pristine ZIF-67 using a one-step hydrothermal method, resulting in a superior OER electrocatalyst. By utilizing the π-conjugated structure, the composite of HHTP@ZIF-67 showed improved OER performance, smaller charge transfer resistance, lower overpotential, and better durability. Thirdly, the optimization of interfacial properties is also a method to regulate the catalytic performance. The efficiency and stability of electrocatalytic water decomposition can be improved by regulating the interfacial properties between the catalyst and the electrolyte or electrode material. This can be achieved by optimizing the interfacial adsorption properties, electron transport efficiency and ion transport rate to improve the overall performance. Fourthly, fine-tuning the catalytic reaction kinetics can also achieve differences in performance. Adjusting reaction conditions such as reaction temperature, electrolyte concentration and electrode potential can change the catalytic reaction kinetics. By optimizing these parameters, the efficiency of the electrocatalytic water decomposition process can be improved. These methods provide promising ways to improve the performance of electrocatalytic water decomposition and contribute to the development of more efficient and sustainable electrochemical water separation technologies. Of course, these other methods mentioned are not important design strategies, but they do provide some ideas for research. To further enhance the electrocatalytic performance of non-derivatized MOF nanosheets, it is crucial to explore advanced modification strategies. These strategies offer pathways to fine-tune the electronic structure, surface chemistry, and catalytic active sites of the materials, thereby improving their efficiency and stability in water electrolysis. Composition regulation is one of the most fundamental strategies, where the substitution of metal nodes or organic linkers can optimize the electronic and catalytic properties. Tailoring the composition allows for the tuning of electronic band structures and catalytic active sites, leading to enhanced performance. Structural regulation involves controlling the dimensionality, porosity, and crystallinity of MOF nanosheets. The manipulation of layer stacking and the creation of defects can significantly influence the exposure of active sites and the overall electron transport pathways. Heterojunction construction creates synergistic effects by combining MOFs with other materials (e.g., metals, oxides, or sulfides), which can enhance charge separation and promote catalytic reactions. The Van der Waals heterojunctions represent a promising area where weak interlayer interactions can facilitate charge transfer while maintaining structural integrity. Electron orbital regulation is a sophisticated strategy that focuses on the tuning of electron configurations at the atomic level. By modulating the electron orbitals of active sites, researchers can manipulate catalytic pathways, improving reaction kinetics. There are also some emerging regulatory strategies in other fields that can be referenced. Amorphous single-atom and diatomic catalysts represent a burgeoning research direction. The amorphous nature of these catalysts offers a high density of unsaturated coordination sites, while single or diatomic configurations maximize atomic utilization, leading to exceptional catalytic activities. Microenvironment regulation aims to tailor the local environment around active sites, such as adjusting pH, ionic strength, or hydrophobicity. This approach allows for the precise control of reaction intermediates and product distribution. Spin state regulation takes advantage of the magnetic properties of certain MOFs to influence catalytic activity through spin polarization effects, which can alter reaction pathways and enhance selectivity. Coupling of Amorphous 2D layered materials is another promising strategy. The combination of amorphous phases with 2D layered structures can provide a high density of active sites and facilitate electron transfer across interfaces, improving overall catalytic efficiency. Indeed, each material design and modification address specific challenges associated with the kinetics and dynamics of electrocatalytic reactions, such as HER and OER. These strategies aim to leverage the intrinsic properties of MOFNSs, such as their high surface area, tunability, and structural diversity, to maximize their efficiency and stability in catalytic processes. Each of these strategies offers a unique angle for improving the performance of MOFNSs in electrocatalytic applications. By combining these approaches, researchers can design MOFs that are not only more effective as catalysts but also more durable and suited to specific applications. The integration of these strategies will contribute significantly to the advancement of sustainable energy technologies, particularly in the areas of energy conversion and storage. As research progresses, these methods are expected to lead to the development of next-generation electrocatalysts with superior performance, pushing the boundaries of what is achievable with 2D MOF-based technologies. 5 Recent progress Researchers have indeed been vigorously pursuing design and development of non-derivatized MOFNSs tailored for water electrolysis, encompassing processes such as HER, OER, and bifunctional water splitting. Several active explorations have contributed significantly to this field, showcasing the potential and advancements in utilizing 2D MOFNSs for efficient water electrolysis. This section aims to discuss and summarize some exemplary research works and the recent progress in the application of 2D MOF-based catalysts for water electrolysis. 5.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction Hydrogen has been considered as a promising alternative to conventional fossil fuels. Water electrolysis is one of the most useful methods to produce high purity hydrogen fuel. In HER, the electrocatalytic performance is related to the catalyst on the electrode. Therefore, the design and synthesis of high-performance (high FE and low η) HER electrocatalysts are essential for the development of hydrogen production. Among the various materials investigated, MOFNSs have garnered significant attention as electrocatalysts for HER. These materials boast desirable pore structures, large specific surface areas, and controllable morphologies, which are advantageous for catalytic processes. The appeal of MOFNSs lies not only in their structural properties but also in their enhanced electrical conductivity and high density of exposed metal sites, which facilitate effective catalytic reactions. Recently, MOFNSs have been explored as electrocatalysts for HER reactions, demonstrating their capability to achieve efficient and stable hydrogen production. The unique combination of conductivity, surface area, and metal site accessibility in MOFNSs allows for optimized electron transfer and gas evolution kinetics, which are essential for high-performance electrolysis. This ongoing research into MOFNSs as HER electrocatalysts underscores the broader movement towards developing more sustainable and efficient methods for hydrogen production, aligning with global energy transition goals. A ligand regulation strategy is explored to improve the performance of electrocatalytic water splitting. Researchers constructs Ni-BDC-based MOF nanosheet arrays with sulfur (S) atoms incorporated (S-Ni BDC), as presented in the Fig. 13(A) [135]. The authors speculate that the improved electrocatalytic activity for HER is attributed to the newly-constructed triangular “Ni2-S1” motif, which are similar to the Fe-S core in [FeFe]-hydrogenase (Fig. 13(B)). The NiBDC and S-NiBDC models share similar d-band centers, but the S-NiBDC model's p-band center increases by 2.53 eV after S species introduction (Fig. 13(C)). Through detailed mechanism analysis and structural characterization, they propose that the Ni sites in triangular “Ni2-S1” motif significantly accelerate the water activation kinetics, while the S site acts as the optimal HER active site by readily capturing hydrogen atoms. As can be seen in Fig. 13(D), S-NiBDC exhibits high current densities, reaching 0.5 and 1.0 A cm−2 at low overpotentials of 285 and 310 mV, respectively, and surpassing benchmark Pt/C at the same current densities. Further, field emission SEM imaging in Fig. 13(E) show no morphological changes or dissolved organic species in the electrolyte of S-NiBDC after HER, even at current density levels up to 1.0 A cm−2. As shown in Fig. 13(F), the structural evolution of S-NiBDC was probed by in situ electrochemical-Raman analysis. The signal intensity decreases with increasing reaction time due to H2 bubble formation, but recovers rapidly without external potential. Meanwhile, an absorption peak located at 2555 cm−1 was detected on S-NiBDC by in situ IR in Fig. 13(G), which gradually intensified between 0 and –0.4 V vs. RHE, and is considered to be an S-H* intermediate, suggesting that the introduction of the S-active species acted to trap H atoms, thus facilitating the evolution of H2. In addition, researchers investigated the deuterium kinetic isotope effect (KIE) of HER, examining proton transfer kinetics during hydrolysis dissociation linked to HO–H bond cleavage, as evidenced in Fig. 13(H). In conclusion, this work suggests that the introduction of S species accelerates water dissociation and promotes the basic HER process by adsorbing H atoms through S–H* bonds, offering a promising approach for designing highly active MOF-based catalysts with triangular active regions. Similarly, Li et al. [136] successfully synthesized three isostructural 2D polyhalogenated Co(II)-coordination polymers, with Co-Cl4-MOF displaying significantly higher electrocatalytic activity for HER. The acetylene black (AB)&Co-Cl4-MOF (3:4) composite exhibited the best HER performance, characterized by a smaller overpotential, lower Tafel slope, and long-term stability. The HER activity of Co-MOF can be controlled by varying the halogens, which influences the electron transport capability of the catalytic sites. In general, MOFNSs have been widely explored for the electrocatalytic HER. In addition, a nanocomposites is synthesized based on MoS2 and MOFNSs, enhancing HER efficiency due to increased electrochemically active surface area, nano-interface, and synergy between MoS2 and Co-MOF [137]. Ruiz-Molina and his coworker [138] successfully created highly uniform nanosheets of [Cu(2,5-pydc) (H2O)] n ·2H2O using ultrasonic exfoliation. These nanosheets showed exceptional electrocatalytic performance, with a reduced overpotential of 340 mV compared to the previous 530 mV. This improvement can be attributed to enhanced electron transfer between the current collector and catalytic sites. Moreover, a highly efficient electrocatalyst is developed for HER by strategically incorporating a conductive Cu-MOF nanoscale layer onto iron hydr(oxy)oxide [Fe(OH) x ] nanobeads (NBs) [139]. Advanced synchrotron radiation characterizations and theoretical calculations revealed that the prominently exposed coordinatively unsaturated Cu1-O2 centers played a crucial role in promoting the generation of *H intermediates, facilitating rapid HER kinetics. This pioneering work provides valuable insights into the design and synthesis of advanced, cost-effective MOF-based electrocatalysts and paves the way for efficient energy conversion and storage. In general, MOFNSs have been widely explored for the electrocatalytic HER. Table 1 summarizes the HER catalytic performance of various MOFNSs. 5.2 Oxygen evolution reaction The electrochemical OER is an important electrochemical reaction used to oxidize water into oxygen. It is a key step in energy conversion technologies such as water splitting and metal-air batteries. However, the high energy consumption and low efficiency of OER limit the practical applications of these technologies. Significant research efforts have been focused on exploiting these properties to overcome the limitations of traditional catalysts used in OER. Innovations in the design and synthesis of MOFNSs have led to materials that reduce the overpotential required for water oxidation. As a result, MOFNSs are paving the way toward more sustainable and efficient energy conversion systems, promising to play a pivotal role in the advancement of technologies crucial for the transition to renewable energy sources. In recent years, researchers have discovered the great potential of MOFNSs in electrochemical OER. The researchers synthesized bulk MOF, 3D MOF and 2D MOF by adjusting the reaction solvents using mild room-temperature stirring reaction conditions as shown in Fig. 14(A) [150]. MOFNSs, with a thickness of about 2.2 nm, is synthesized by simple stirring of the reaction mixture of iron/cobalt salts and BDC in the presence of triethylamine and water. Figs. 14(B) and (C) show that 2D MOF performs much better than bulk MOF, 3D MOF. Similarly, Researchers have improved OER performance by converting bulk MOF to 2D MOF through balanced thermal decomposition and liquid nitrogen stripping (Fig. 14(D)) [78]. The MOF after the five times treatment consisted mainly of nanosheets with a thickness of less than 10 nm. As shown in Fig. 14(E), CuBDC crystal structure has a typical layer-by-layer structure, with copper paddle wheels coordinated by N,N-dimethylformamide molecules, forming a hydrogen bond network. In the intralayer, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands and Cu-based metal nodes coordinate to create a 2D landscape. The researchers use a 150 °C heat treatment strategy to weaken interlayer bonds, then immersed the heated CuBDC into L-N2 until it was completely gamified. This rapid temperature drop caused curling and delamination of CuBDC, and with the expansion of L-N2 into gaseous N2, CuBDC exfoliation was achieved. Fig. 14(F) shows the morphology of CuBDC before and after stripping. The researchers also synthesized Ni-based MOFs to demonstrate the universality of the method. Figs. 14(G) and (H) demonstrate the improved OER performance of Cu-based MOFNSs and Ni-based MOFNSs relative to bulk MOF, respectively. Furthermore, a rapid and efficient method is successfully demonstrated for synthesizing ultrathin nanosheets of NiCoFe-MOFs, which exhibited cobalt cation vacancies and improved OER activities [100]. The as-synthesized MW-NiCoFe-MOFs displayed outstanding OER performance, requiring only a low overpotential of 243 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in an alkaline medium. Remarkably, this overpotential was 22 mV lower than that of the sample without microwave treatment. Furthermore, the nanosheets showed a small Tafel slope of 48.1 mV dec−1. The enhanced OER activities were attributed to the increased active sites and enhanced charge transfer within the MOF framework. This work presents a facile and rapid approach for synthesizing MOF nanosheets, while also providing insights into regulating the electronic structure of MOFs for electrocatalysis. Jayaramulu and colleagues [85] successfully synthesize cobalt-based ZIF-9(III) nanosheets using a simple and convenient mechanochemical grinding method followed by ultrasonication-assisted liquid-phase exfoliation. These nanosheets exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance for OER. Importantly, the electrocatalytic activity of the Co-ZIF-9(III) nanosheet-derived coating in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH was significantly higher in terms of current density and overpotential compared to the bulk Co-ZIF-9 counterparts. This improvement can be attributed to the presence of more accessible active sites in the exfoliated 2D Co-ZIF-9(III) electrocatalyst as compared to its 3D bulk MOF crystal counterparts. In addition, researchers synthesized hybrid Ni-based MOFs nanosheets decorated with Fe-MOF nanoparticles using mild conditions [151]. As a proof-of-concept, the introduction of electrochemically inert Fe-MOF nanoparticles onto active MOFNSs nanosheets resulted in a remarkable enhancement of catalytic activity for water oxidation catalysis. The improved performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect between Ni active centres and Fe species, along with the unique 2D nanosheet morphology. Huang et al. [54] developed a unique 3D pillared-layer MOF with the ability to selectively oxidize and remove the pillars while preserving the 2D layers. The resulting ultrathin MOFNSs exhibited exceptional OER activities, combining the advantages of heterogeneous catalysts (low overpotential and high current density) and homogeneous catalysts (high TOF value). This not only enhances our understanding of the catalyst evolution process but also provides detailed and reliable structural information for the final catalyst. There are numerous excellent research studies on the utilization of MOFNSs for electrocatalytic OER. However, a detailed discussion of these works is beyond the scope of this review. Table 2 summarizes the OER catalytic performance of various MOFNSs. 5.3 Bifunctional water splitting Electrocatalytic bifunctional overall water splitting is a catalytic process that simultaneously decomposes water into hydrogen and oxygen. The reactions occur on separate electrodes, with hydrogen gas produced at the cathode and oxygen gas produced at the anode, resulting in the decomposition of water into hydrogen and oxygen. However, achieving efficient electrocatalytic bifunctional overall water splitting still faces challenges. To address these issues, in recent years, MOFNSs have been introduced into electrocatalytic bifunctional overall water splitting. MOFNSs have shown great potential as a new type of catalyst material in electrocatalytic bifunctional overall water splitting. With further research and optimization of MOFNSs, they are expected to play a crucial role in bifunctional water splitting, thus driving the development of green energy. The researchers present a novel electrocatalyst with 0.85 wt% Ru nanoclusters anchored on Cr-doped Fe-MOFs (Ru@Cr-FeMOF), which promotes rapid electron transfer and manipulates the highest occupancy of the Ru sites in the center of the d orbitals and d bands (Fig. 15(A) ) [152]. The catalyst exhibits excellent reactivity in alkaline solutions and achieves excellent water splitting performance at industrial grade current densities. The interaction mechanism of Cr–O–Ru formed after doping Cr in FeMOF shows that abundant empty orbitals near the Fermi cause the p Z and p X of O orbitals to move closer to the Fermi level. Ru anchors primarily with Cr–O bonds rich in HOMO electrons, and the p X and p Z orbitals of O interact with the dX2–Y2 and d XZ orbitals of Ru to form Cr–O–Ru bonds (Fig. 15(B)). The catalyst achieved overall water splitting current density of 500 mA cm−2 at 1.68 V and 1000 mA cm−2 at 1.72 V, meeting the existing industrial-grade electrolytic water catalyst standard (Fig. 15(C)). The catalyst demonstrated superior performance compared to the reported bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalysts for water separation, indicating its potential for water separation applications (Fig. 15(D)). In conjunction, the researchers develop a versatile dissolution-recrystallisation method for the preparation of 2D conductive MOF arrays with excellent electrochemical reactive structural features as shown in Fig. 15(E) [103]. Remarkably, NiFe-MOF array electrodes can achieve a high current density of 500 mA cm−2 at 1.87 V, with smaller voltages by 40–100 mV compared to commercial precious catalysts in the current density range of 10–500 mA cm−2 as depicted in Fig. 15(F). A water splitting cell was connected to a commercial silicon solar cell to simulate water photolysis in nature. Under irradiation of air mass (AM) 1.5G 100 mW cm−2, a current density of 17 mA cm−2 was achieved without external bias. This phenomenon is consistent with chopped illumination of solar water splitting with little current generated in the dark. The solar-to-hydrogen efficiency was 17.69% as shown in Fig. 15(G), and the solar-water splitting system can work stably for at least 30 h. In addition, researchers utilized a one-step solvothermal method to fabricate ultrathin nanosheet arrays of 2D NiFe MOF-74 [141]. The collaboration between Ni and Fe in the NiFe MOF-74 yielded layered sheets. This collaboration not only optimized the morphology but also enhanced the electron environment and reduced charge transfer resistance. As a result, the NiFe MOF-74 displayed remarkable bifunctional activity towards both OER and HER, delivering a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a mere cell voltage of 1.58 V. Notably, the electrocatalytic stability of the NiFe MOF-74 was demonstrated by the minimal changes in shape and structure observed after 5000 cycles of CV testing, showcasing the impeccable stability attributed to its interconnected 3D structure. Duan et al. [16] have presented a ground-breaking universal strategy for fabricating ultrathin nanosheet arrays of MOFNSs, including cobalt, manganese, titanium, and molybdenum-based MOFs. This innovative approach demonstrates exceptional adaptability, allowing for the preparation of various metal-based MOFNSs. The resulting material showcases a multitude of impressive features, including significantly enhanced catalytic performances, high activity levels, favourable kinetics, and exceptional durability in electrocatalysis applications such as OER, HER, and overall water splitting. These findings challenge the prevailing notion that MOFs themselves act as inert catalysts for electrochemical reactions. With the growing demand for catalyst advancements in industrial applications, the significance of dual-functional MOFNSs has garnered increasing attention from researchers. Table 3 summarizes MOFNSs for electrocatalytic water splitting in recent years. Building upon the discussed advancements, it is clear that non-derivatized MOFNSs offer a transformative potential in the field of electrocatalysis, especially for water splitting. However, several key areas deserve further exploration and refinement. Firstly, although substantial progress in MOFs catalysts for water electrolysis, the achievements lie in the design of MOFs electrocatalysts in alkaline system. The development of highly efficient MOFs catalysts for acidic water electrolysis remains great challenge. Then, while significant progress has been made in improving catalytic activity and stability, the scalability, cost-effectiveness, and industrial grade long-term stability of these MOFNS materials remain critical challenges. Future research should focus on developing more efficient and economically viable synthesis techniques that can be applied on an industrial scale without compromising performance. Moreover, the mechanistic understanding of how specific structural features influence the catalytic behavior of MOFNSs is still incomplete. A deeper exploration of the interaction between metal nodes, ligands, and reaction intermediates at the atomic level could unlock new possibilities for tailoring these materials with unprecedented precision. This includes investigating the dynamic evolution of active sites during electrocatalytic processes, which can provide insights into how to stabilize and enhance performance over extended operational periods. In addition, integrating MOFNSs into hybrid systems, such as combining them with other catalytic materials or incorporating them into innovative reactor designs, could further boost their efficiency and practical applicability. This multi-material approach may lead to synergistic effects that surpass the capabilities of individual components, thus pushing the boundaries of water splitting technology. Finally, while the focus has largely been on HER and OER, the broader application potential of MOFNSs in other electrochemical reactions, such as CO2 reduction and nitrogen fixation, should not be overlooked. Exploring these avenues could expand the utility of MOF-based catalysts in sustainable energy conversion beyond just water splitting, contributing to a more comprehensive solution for renewable energy challenges. 6 Summary and outlook In summary, various MOFNSs, including nanosheets, nanofilms, as well as their assemblies of nanospheres and nanoflowers, have gained significant interest in the field of electrocatalysis such as HER, OER, and bifunctional catalysis reactions. In the case of HER, MOFNSs have shown promise due to their large surface area, accessible active sites, and excellent electronic conductivity, effectively catalyzing the reduction of protons to generate hydrogen fuel. Customizable pore sizes and structures further facilitate the enhancement of HER activity. Similarly, MOFNSs exhibit remarkable electrocatalytic activity and stability towards OER, promoting the water oxidation process to produce oxygen molecules. The exceptional porosity and abundant unsaturated metal sites of MOFNSs enhance the mass transfer during electrocatalysis, thereby boosting reaction rates and reducing reaction overpotential. Moreover, MOFNSs have emerged as promising candidates for bifunctional electrocatalysis, where both HER and OER can be efficiently catalyzed using the same material. This capability enables the development of cost-effective and efficient water splitting devices for large-scale green hydrogen production. Despite the great potential of MOFNSs, their practical industrial application in water electrolysis remains challenges such as unsatisfactory conductivity, activity, stability, and complex synthesis process. To promote breakthroughs for development and industrial transformation, several key challenges and prospects to enhance the performance of MOFNSs electrocatalysts and accelerate their application process are described below (Fig. 16 ). 6.1 Large-scale production Firstly, the synthesis and massive production of MOFs still face limitations, which puts forward impending requirements toward efficient synthesis strategies. Post-synthetic treatments like the exfoliation method are often employed to obtain ultrathin MOFNSs with enhanced electrocatalytic activity for water splitting. However, achieving controlled synthesis of MOFNSs with the desired morphology, size, and high catalytic activity remains great challenging. Both top-down and bottom-up synthesis approaches for MOFNSs have limitations, thereby underscoring the need for universally applicable synthesis methods that offer broader applicability and scalability for future advancements in this field. Secondly, in view of practical application, there is a strong emphasis on the rapid and large-scale synthesis of MOFs under mild conditions, such as ultrasonication and in-situ growth approaches at room temperature and pressure. The realization of simple but effective strategies will provide a solid foundation for the industrial applications of MOF materials. 6.2 Advanced characterization techniques Despite substantial progress in various in-situ, ex-situ, and operando characterization instruments, current technologies are typically limited to monitoring stable intermediates and final states, neglecting shorter-lived transient species. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop move advanced characterization techniques for offering insights into the comprehensive understanding of the real mechanism, enabling rational design and optimization of electrocatalysts. Some emerging characterization methods, such as time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry, neutron reflectometry, dielectric relaxation spectroscopy, in-situ and ultrafast time-resolved spectroscopic techniques, play a crucial role in unravelling the structure-property relationships and understanding the reaction mechanisms of MOFNSs. Additionally, artificial intelligence is also becoming integrated into research. By employing machine learning algorithms to analyze vast amounts of data and identify key trends, researchers can make more informed decisions in the MOFNSs design process. Moreover, the combination of human expertise and artificial intelligence can lead to a significant breakthrough and innovation in the electrolysis field of MOFNSs, enabling researchers to minimize errors, optimize experimental conditions, and ultimately achieve more efficient and effective results. Overall, the synergy between advanced theoretical modeling, experimental characterization techniques, and artificial intelligence presents a unique opportunity for researchers to promote the development of high-performance MOFNSs. 6.3 Industrial current density and stability Although MOFNSs have shown effectiveness as electrocatalysts for water splitting, their current density and durability in electrocatalytic water splitting still far from industrial applications. Therefore, the development of MOFNSs with industrial current density and stability is a key precondition for practical application. Coordination engineering strategies, focusing on metal ions and organic ligands, hold great promise for developing high-performance MOFNSs for industrial water electrolysis. The valence state of the metal ion and the length, conjugation, and functionalization of the organic ligand significantly impact the catalytic activity and durability of MOFs. Additionally, apart from the stability of the electrocatalysts themselves, their mechanical shedding during the water splitting process should also be considered. New technologies for fabricating electrodes, such as porous vertical MOF arrays and freestanding electrodes, should receive more attention. Therefore, future research should focus on the development of MOF-based electrodes with ampere-level currents and ultra-long-time stability, signalling the transition of water electrolysis from laboratory to industrial applications. In laboratory studies, researchers generally pay more attention to the improvement of performance and the exploration of reaction mechanism of catalysts, which is crucial for the development of high-performance catalysts in practical applications. However, for industrialization process, the catalysts must exhibit superior scalability, long-term stability, and impurity tolerance. Additionally, they must be capable to operate at high current densities while maintaining cost-effectiveness. These requirements lead to significant differences in the design and optimization of industrial catalysts compared to laboratory materials. Industrial catalysts not only need to deliver high performance but also maintain durability and longevity under real-world operating conditions. Moreover, scaling up from laboratory synthesis to industrial production is not necessarily straightforward, as various conditions need further optimization. Industrial equipment and systems are more sophisticated and impose higher demands on catalysts. Thus, comprehensive research is required to meet the stringent requirements of industrial applications but remains challenging. 6.4 Application in acidic media and seawater electrolysis The electrolysis system also plays an important role in electrocatalytic processes due to the cost and efficiency considerations. Currently, PEMWE has attracted much attention and emerged as a promising technology for large-scale hydrogen production. However, developing active and stable MOF catalysts for in acidic media has become an unprecedented challenge for water electrolysis. The shift towards acidic systems necessitates the development of MOFNSs with excellent activity and chemical stability simultaneously. Therefore, a significantly growing attention is exploring strategies to improve the corrosion resistance and catalytic performance of MOFNSs in acidic electrolytes. Simultaneously, from the perspective of water resources, increasing researchers are gradually considering the use of seawater instead of fresh water, and even the use of municipal wastewater. This shift requires materials with exceptional selectivity, activity, and durability. It is worth noting that MOFs possess unique physicochemical property such as the customizable components and tunable pore structures, which offer unparalleled advantages in efficient and stable seawater electrolysis. For instance, precise control over the local environment of metal active sites in MOFs by functionalization or domain restriction strategies allow for the regulation of ion selectivity and enhanced resistance to chloride corrosion during seawater electrolysis process. These improvements contribute to more efficient and stable hydrogen production from seawater. Therefore, researchers are actively exploring various strategies to further enhance the performance and stability of MOFNSs in seawater and wastewater electrolysis. 6.5 Economic viability The application of MOFNSs in water electrolysis shows significant potential, despite currently high production costs. As synthesis methods improve and new materials are developed, these costs are expected to decrease. Presently, the high cost of MOFNSs is primarily due to the expensive metal precursors and complex synthesis processes. However, optimizing synthesis routes and using more affordable raw materials can significantly reduce production costs. While initial investments are high, the efficiency and durability of MOFNSs in water electrolysis help lower long-term operational costs. Efficient catalysts can enhance electrolysis efficiency and reduce power consumption, while their excellent stability and corrosion resistance can lower maintenance and replacement frequencies. Utilizing renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power for water electrolysis can further reduce overall energy costs and decrease carbon emissions. Government support for clean energy and hydrogen technologies, including subsidies, tax incentives, and research funding, will also lower the economic barriers for MOFNSs water electrolysis and promote its commercialization. Despite the challenges, through technological innovation and cost control, MOFNSs are poised to become efficient and economical catalysts for water electrolysis in the future, contributing to the widespread adoption of clean energy. Therefore, the economic viability of MOFNSs water electrolysis is significantly enhanced by reducing material costs, optimizing equipment and maintenance expenses, leveraging renewable energy sources, and receiving policy and market support. These factors interact to lay a solid foundation for the widespread application of MOFNSs in the field of water electrolysis. Overall, although challenges remain, the extensive attention and effort from researchers across the world will promote the rapid development of non-derivatized MOF nanosheet electrocatalysts, as well as large-scale hydrogen production by water electrolysis. Lei Shi (National Center for Nanoscience and Technology) received his Ph.D. degree from Beijing University of Chemical Technology in 2022. Currently, He is a postdoctoral fellow in National Center for Nanoscience and Technology. His research interests focus on the MOF and COF-based nanomaterials for water electrolysis, electrochemical CO2 reduction and small molecule electrooxidation. Di Liu (China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing)) received her B.S. degree from Shandong University in 2011 and Ph.D. degree from Tsinghua University in 2016. She is currently an associate professor in China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing). Her current research is focused on the rational synthesis and mechanism exploration of perylene diimide (PDI)-based organic semiconductor materials for visible-light-driven photocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis. Shenlong Zhao (National Center for Nanoscience and Technology, Chinese Academy of Science) received his B.E. degree from Shandong University in 2011. He obtained his Ph.D. degree from the Harbin Institute of Technology and the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology in 2017. And then, he was a postdoctoral fellow in the University of New South Wales and a FH Loxton Research Fellow in the University of Sydney. Currently, He is a professor/principal investigator in National Center for Nanoscience and Technology. His research interests focus on the preparation and application of functional inorganic and organic carbon nanomaterials for energy conversion and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Water splitting powered by clean electricity is a sustainable and promising approach to produce green hydrogen. Currently, noble metal (e.g. Iridium, Ruthenium, Platinum)-based catalysts are most widely used for water splitting electrolysis. However, noble metal-based catalysts often suffer from multiple disadvantages, including high cost, low selectivity and poor durability. The emergence of metal-organic framework nanosheets (MOFNSs) attracts significant attention due to their unique advantages. Here, a concise, yet comprehensive and critical, review of recent advances in the field of MOFNSs is provided. This review explains the fundamental oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalytic mechanisms as well as key characterization techniques for the structure-activity relationship study are discussed. Moreover, it discusses efficient design strategies and the brief research advances of MOFNSs in HER, OER, and bifunctional electrocatalysis, along with some challenges and opportunities.
